docs.lead_paragraph: Thousands of postal employees and workers on Capitol Hill who took antibiotics because they were exposed to anthrax two months ago now face a difficult new medical decision: whether to take an anthrax vaccine to forestall the slim and theoretical possibility that they may still develop the disease. And the advice they are getting from federal health officials -- consult your doctor and decide for yourself -- is less helpful than many workers would like. In defending themselves against growing criticism for not making a firm recommendation, health officials last week were forced to do what they rarely do -- confess ignorance about the risks of a disease and its treatment options. It was the latest acknowledgment that government officials had been overconfident in saying they were well prepared for a bioterrorist attack.

headline.main: In Offering Anthrax Vaccine, Officials Admit to Unknowns

docs.abstract: Thousands of postal employees and Capitol Hill workers who took antibiotics because they were exposed to anthrax two months ago are getting little help from federal health officials in deciding whether to take anthrax vaccine; officials admit their ignorance about risks of disease and treatment options, acknowledging government officials were overconfident in saying they were prepared for bioterrorist attack; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: How to count the many differences between President Bush and former President Bill Clinton? Yet another way emerged last week in the closing fizzle of the first session of the 107th Congress, when Mr. Bush's style of lobbying, such as it is, emerged as a stunning contrast to the midnight strikes of the 42nd president. ''Clinton called late at night, and Bush calls early in the morning,'' said Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana, Mr. Bush's favorite Democrat. ''That's pretty significant, because for neither one of them was I awake.''

headline.main: White House Letter; When Lobbying, No. 43 Uses a Lighter Touch

docs.abstract: Pres Bush has more subtle approach than his predecessor in lobbying legislators; he is also less likely to be involved with details of legislation, looking more at big picture (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For many Americans, 2001 has been a difficult year financially, with continued stock market volatility, rising unemployment and recession. No one knows what the new year will bring, but experts recommend a few moves -- call them financial resolutions -- that may improve the outlook. Though most are basic, they seem more important than ever these days.

headline.main: New Year's Resolutions For Financial Health

docs.abstract: Experts suggest six ways people can improve their financial health in 2002 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WITH a clatter of stadium-style seats, several hundred drug stock analysts rushed from the crowded amphitheater in Merck's gleaming $250 million headquarters in Whitehouse Station, N.J., on Dec. 12. Racing into the nearby atrium, they began feverishly contacting their trading desks on their cellphones and Blackberries to report a bombshell for investors. Judy C. Lewent, the chief financial officer, had just told the analysts that Merck, a pillar of the pharmaceutical industry and one of its most consistently highly profitable companies, expected no growth in earnings in 2002. The analysts had been expecting 8 percent.

headline.main: The Drug-Price Express Runs Into a Wall

docs.abstract: Merck and other pharmaceutical companies encounter resistance to practice of continually promoting new drugs, typically with higher prices, that are sometimes no better than older ones; resistance comes from consumers, who are bearing more of costs of treatment, insurers, government and employers; power shift in health care is already affecting drug industry revenue; many companies are now putting their main research efforts into seeking 'clinical breakthrough' products as opposed to 'me-too' products; photo; table; chart (M)

byline.original: By MILT FREUDENHEIM and MELODY PETERSEN

docs.lead_paragraph: THE world did not stop on Sept. 11; it only seemed that way. Many people, riveted by the extraordinary, paid little attention to anything else. Life went on, of course. Argentina is in trouble, the Yankees lost the World Series, the Democrats and Republicans are fighting about everything but terrorism, and V. S. Naipaul won the Nobel Prize. Muggles in droves went to the Harry Potter movie.

headline.main: Imagine; Headlines From the Cutting Room Floor

docs.abstract: Prescription drug benefits for elderly, which all politicians agree are badly needed, is one of many items on domestic agenda that has lost steam since Sept 11, when terrorism and slowing economy transformed agenda in Washington and created some grim new budget realities (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: It is very disheartening to learn that, once again, Congress has failed to recognize that mental illness should be as insurable as physical illness (''Drive for More Mental Health Coverage Fails in Congress,'' news article, Dec. 19). This decision can only reinforce the public perception that the mentally ill should simply ''snap out of it.'' I harbor no ill will toward those in Congress who may never have witnessed a frightening psychotic episode in a loved one. Perhaps, to fully understand the horrors of schizophrenia or clinical depression, a little time in a psychiatric hospital would be well spent.

headline.main: Failure in Congress On Mental Illness

docs.abstract: Roy E Lawrence letter deplores Congress's failure to recognize that mental illness should be as insurable as physical illness (Dec 19 article)

docs.lead_paragraph: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. MICHAEL EDWARD ROBERTS Firehouse Psychologist When Michael Edward Roberts was just 4, his father took him to a firehouse and sat him on a rig parked there. That's all it took. From that moment on, life was a countdown to the Fire Academy. He took time to get a degree in psychology from the State University of New York at Buffalo, but ''he knew without a doubt what he was going to do,'' said his father, Thomas Roberts, a retired New York City fire captain. ''He'd say the only decision he needed to make was whether to grow up, or become a firefighter.'' Finally, in February 1998, Michael Edward Roberts was formally admitted to the academy. He ended up at Ladder Company 35 near Lincoln Center. ''He was so happy,'' said his sister, Lisa.

headline.main: A Knack for Inventing, a Love of Animals, and a Flair for the Dramatic
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: PORTRAITS OF GRIEF: THE VICTIMS

docs.lead_paragraph: Congress snarled its way out of town today, after a session as remarkable for its mood swings as the laws it passed but ending with dramatic inaction on the economy. Although the first midsession switch of control of the Senate in history slowed legislative action, the first session of the 107th Congress passed more legislation than first sessions usually do. That record was spurred by a rare month of bipartisanship after the Sept. 11 attacks.

headline.main: After Twists Of a Novel, Congress Goes Home

docs.abstract: First session of 107th Congress passes more legislation than first sessions usually do, spurred by rare month of bipartisanship after Sept 11 terrorist attacks; review of bills passed, including those related to Sept 11 attacks, and unfinished business; photos; chart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Our nation is capable of clarity and just action. We track down the ''evil one'' in Tora Bora, and battle hard to preserve our liberty. Sadly, this clarity of purpose vanishes when it comes to mental illness (news article, Dec. 19). We know that the brain is an organ, like the heart, lung or kidney, and that it, too, can become sick. The consequences for those afflicted with mental illness are no less an intrusion on liberty than a terrorist attack. Yet when Congress has the opportunity to pass legislation that would provide parity for coverage of mental illness, it shirks its duty.

headline.main: Failure in Congress On Mental Illness

docs.abstract: Joseph Sokal letter deplores Congress's failure to recognize that mental illness should be as insurable as physical illness (Dec 19 article)
